Authors:
Adam L Healey, David J. Lee, Agnelo Furtado, Robert J.
Henry
Title:
Evidence of inter-sectional chloroplast capture in Corymbia
among sections Torellianae and Maculatae
Keywords:
eucalypts; Corymbia citriodora subspecies citriodora;
Corymbia citriodora subspecies variegata; Corymbia torelliana; Corymbia
henryi; Torellianae; Maculatae; chloroplast capture; reticulate
evolution
Abstract:
Background and Aims: Chloroplast capture through
hybridization and introgression is well described within Eucalyptus.
Despite the propensity of the Corymbia genus (a eucalypt) to form
hybrids from wide crosses, description of chloroplast capture in
Corymbia is limited to section Maculatae. In this study we aim to
investigate evidence of intersectional chloroplast capture between
sections Torellianae and Maculatae. Methods: Using whole genome
next-generation sequencing data, the complete chloroplast genomes were
assembled from four Corymbia taxa: C. citriodora subspecies citriodora,
C. citriodora subspecies variegata, C. henryi, and C. torelliana,
represented by eight genotypes. Chloroplast and nuclear phylogenies were
generated by maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods. Key Results:
Phylogenetic analysis and comparison among Corymbia chloroplast genomes
and nuclear external transcribed spacer sequences revealed chloroplast
capture among Corymbia species across distinct sections Torellianae and
Maculatae within subgenus Blakella. Reticulate evolution, well described
within Eucalyptus, likely extends into Corymbia as evidenced by
incongruent plastid and nuclear phylogenetic trees. Conclusions: This is
the first evidence of chloroplast capture described using whole
chloroplast genomes and the first documentation of chloroplast capture
between sections within eucalypt taxa, suggesting the importance of
hybridization and introgression during the evolution of eucalypts.
